tally.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: a record of how much you have spent, won etc by a particular point in time
tally.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: the two goals that took his tally for Scotland to 15
Keep a tally of  (=write down) the number of cars that pass.
tally.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: if numbers or statements tally, they match exactly
tally.translation[1].definitions[0].exam: Some of the records held by the accounts departments did not tally.
The number of ballot papers did not tally with the number of voters.
tally.translation[2].definitions[0].defi: if numbers or statements tally, they match each other exactly
tally.translation[2].definitions[0].exam: If the figures don’t quite tally, you might be missing an invoice.
The original estimate did not tally with the final bill.
tally.translation[2].definitions[1].defi: to calculate the total number of things done, points won etc
tally.translation[2].definitions[1].exam: Let’s tally up how much we’ve spent.
tally.translation[3].definitions[0].defi: a continuous record of how much a person or organization has spent, obtained, won etc so far
tally.translation[3].definitions[0].exam: Please keep a tally of how many books you sell.
tally.translation[3].definitions[1].defi: the amount or number of something
tally.translation[3].definitions[1].exam: The company has only one-third its usual tally of accountants because so many have taken voluntary redundancy
